content:
The "Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act of 1997" amends the number and composition of circuits in the United States. It changes the number of circuits from thirteen to fourteen and reorganizes the ninth and twelfth circuits. The ninth circuit now includes Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands, while the twelfth circuit includes Alaska, Idaho, Montana, Oregon, and Washington. The "Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act of 1997" amends the number and composition of circuits in the United States. It changes the number of circuits from thirteen to fourteen and reorganizes the ninth and twelfth circuits. The ninth circuit now includes Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands, while the twelfth circuit includes Alaska, Idaho, Montana, Oregon, and Washington. The table in section 44(a) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to reflect these changes in the number of circuit judges and their respective locations. The "Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act of 1997" reassigns circuit judges from the former ninth circuit to the new ninth circuit or twelfth circuit based on their official station. Senior judges can elect their assignment and notify the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. SEC. 7. SENIORITY OF JUDGES. The seniority of judges assigned or electing to be assigned under this Act shall run from the date of their commission as a judge of the former ninth circuit. SEC. 8. APPLICATION TO CASES. The provisions in this section apply to cases where an appeal or proceeding was filed with the former ninth circuit before the effective date of this Act. If the matter has been submitted for decision, further proceedings will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. If the matter has not been submitted, it will be transferred to the appropriate court as if the Act had been in effect at the time the appeal was taken or proceeding commenced. The provisions in this section state that further proceedings in a case filed before the effective date of the Act will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. A petition for rehearing or rehearing en banc will also be treated as if the Act had not been enacted. If rehearing en banc is granted, the matter will be reheard by a court as if the Act had not been enacted. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS.

    The Act defines the "former ninth circuit," "new ninth circuit," and "twelfth circuit."

SEC. 10. ADMINISTRATION.

    The court of appeals for the ninth circuit may take administrative action to implement the Act and will cease to exist for administrative purposes on July 1, 1999.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 1997.
